paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses various variants of the TTR gene, particularly focusing on their stability and implications in transthyretin amyloidosis.

patients.demographics: Age range: 70 years and older, both male and female

individual_records.phenotype_details: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Approximately 80% of patients older than 70 years of age with ATTR-CM had ATTRwt-CM.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Approximately 80% of patients older than 70 years of age with ATTR-CM had ATTRwt-CM.

functional_data.summary: The study developed an ELISA system to assess TTR stability, showing that TTR variants exhibit different stability profiles.

variants.segregation_data: The study suggests that TTR instability is associated with the pathophysiology of ATTRwt and ATTRv.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of TTR stability in the context of ATTRwt-CM.
key_quotes: The residual TTR tetramer ratio was significantly lower in the ATTRwt-CM group than in the control group.
TTR with the T119M mutation, a stable variant, exhibited kinetic stability comparable with that of wild-type TTR.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear information on TTR variants.
